content.raw: Nice, should be useful for generating changelogs. The only issue is that sometimes we merge a pull request to one release branch and then merge forward to the other ones, so the pull requests won't show up in the logs of the more recent release branches.
content.html: Nice, should be useful for generating changelogs. The only issue is that sometimes we merge a pull request to one release branch and then merge forward to the other ones, so the pull requests won't show up in the logs of the more recent release branches.

content.raw: any idea about how to detect that and include a note in the summary?
content.html: any idea about how to detect that and include a note in the summary?

content.raw: I'm still thinking about it. We would have to look at each merge commit and show commits from both of those branches. I'm not sure if there's an easy way to do that, or if we need a fancier script.
content.html: I'm still thinking about it. We would have to look at each merge commit and show commits from both of those branches. I'm not sure if there's an easy way to do that, or if we need a fancier script.

content.raw: What about filtering all the "summary" entries in the log that does not mention (pull request ...) and are not related to releasing (tags)? They should be included as are entries coming from non pull request in bitbucket which are useful to mention.
content.html: What about filtering all the "summary" entries in the log that does not mention (pull request ...) and are not related to releasing (tags)? They should be included as are entries coming from non pull request in bitbucket which are useful to mention.

content.raw:
Going a little further with this (complicated):
~~~
# show only merge commits between 3.1 branch and 3.0.0 tag
$ hg log -b gazebo_3.1 -P gazebo3_3.0.0 -m
~~~
This shows pull request merges and manual merges from release branches. If you can filter out the pull requests, then you will see commits like the following:
~~~
changeset:   15667:3ca5a42411b9
branch:      gazebo_3.1
parent:      15635:fdb5ca8c9325
parent:      15665:2185d87124de
user:        Steve Peters <scpeters@osrfoundation.org>
date:        Fri Jul 18 15:30:40 2014 -0700
summary:     2.2 -> 3.1
~~~
There's two parents there: fdb5ca8c9325 and 2185d87124de
~~~
$ hg log -r "ancestor(fdb5ca8c9325,2185d87124de)"
changeset:   15523:0199b245ffd5
branch:      gazebo_2.2
parent:      15408:d8e4649faea6
parent:      15508:9ac4ff7c7a58
user:        Steven Peters <scpeters@osrfoundation.org>
date:        Wed Jul 09 14:49:53 2014 -0700
summary:     Merged in issue_1208_2.2 (pull request #1107)
~~~
The common ancestor of those parents is 0199b245ffd5. The difference between each parent and the ancestor:
~~~
$ export PARENT1=fdb5ca8c9325
$ export PARENT2=2185d87124de
$ export ANCESTOR=0199b245ffd5
$ hg log -r ${PARENT1} -P ${ANCESTOR}
changeset:   15635:fdb5ca8c9325
branch:      gazebo_3.1
parent:      15538:7ae807f7caad
parent:      15633:597b9a77a645
user:        Steven Peters <scpeters@osrfoundation.org>
date:        Wed Jul 16 13:09:56 2014 -0700
summary:     Merged in require_sdf_2.0.1 (pull request #1146)

$ hg log -r ${PARENT2} -P ${ANCESTOR}
changeset:   15665:2185d87124de
branch:      gazebo_2.2
parent:      15523:0199b245ffd5
parent:      15661:efc2c4c6bcf8
user:        Steven Peters <scpeters@osrfoundation.org>
date:        Fri Jul 18 15:27:38 2014 -0700
summary:     Merged in inertia_ratio_engines (pull request #1149)

~~~
The second listed parent is the earlier release branch, which shows that the merge commit 3ca5a42411b9 corresponds to pull request #1149.

That's complicated, probably not worth it for now.

Going a little further with this (complicated):

# show only merge commits between 3.1 branch and 3.0.0 tag
$ hg log -b gazebo_3.1 -P gazebo3_3.0.0 -m

This shows pull request merges and manual merges from release branches. If you can filter out the pull requests, then you will see commits like the following:

changeset:   15667:3ca5a42411b9

$ export PARENT1=fdb5ca8c9325

content.raw: One way to handle this is to update the changelog for the version that received the original PR. This would mark the gazebo version that first received the changes. The downside is that we'd have to figure out which changes are new for each released version of Gazebo, but I think we could do this based on date.
content.html: One way to handle this is to update the changelog for the version that received the original PR. This would mark the gazebo version that first received the changes. The downside is that we'd have to figure out which changes are new for each released version of Gazebo, but I think we could do this based on date.
